Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Global patterns of fish functional diversity and trait convergence along species richness and environmental gradients
Award.AbstractNarration:
Community assembly processes (CAP), such as environmental filtering, limiting similarity, and neutral processes, explain species coexistence and community composition. Environmental filtering posits that environmental conditions allow species with certain traits to establish and persist, causing species traits to cluster. Alternatively, limiting similarity is the idea that species with similar traits will competitively exclude each other, producing an assemblage with an overdispersion of traits. Trait dispersion patterns are used to determine the importance of these scale-dependent, niche-based (i.e., biological, chemical, and physical factors in the environment) processes in structuring assemblages relative to neutral processes. The search for general patterns of these processes has been hindered by several factors including: lack of large-scale studies, inconsistent and erroneous methodologies, and changes in CAP along environmental gradients and species richness. Convergent evolution of functional groups within independent zoogeographic regions would provide additional evidence for ecological mechanisms influencing assemblage structure. A major challenge for ecology is to understand how assemblages are functionally structured and how CAP, at varying spatial scales, influence biodiversity patterns.

This dissertation research project has three aims that address these issues: (1) examine knowledge gaps regarding functional diversity and convergence patterns of fish assemblages at a global scale; (2) determine relative contribution of limiting similarity and environmental filtering to neutral processes at three scales using recently proposed analytical methods; and (3) assess changes in functional diversity and community assemblage processes across environment and species richness gradients. Understanding the relative role of niche-based and stochastic processes at various scales is a central goal in community ecology and crucial for not only conservation and management of assemblages but for understanding the effect of the ever-changing environment on communities as a whole. To effectively address these aims, fish assemblages will be sampled in forty wadable streams in five different zoogeographic regions of varying species richness. Traits with well-known relationships to trophic ecology, habitat use, and life history will be measured for each assemblage. The relative contribution of community assembly processes will be tested at three spatial scales using new methods for analysis of functional trait dispersion. Functional diversity indices will be compared across gradients of stream size and species richness. Lastly, patterns of convergence of functional structure and community assembly processes in different zoogeographic systems will be analyzed using multivariate statistical methods. Field research will involve collaborations with scientists and students from several countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major challenge for ecology is to understand how assemblages are functionally structured and how community assembly processes influence biodiversity patterns. Community assembly processes, including environmental filtering, limiting similarity and neutral processes, play a major role in species coexistence and community composition. Environmental filtering occurs when certain traits are required in order for species to become established and persist in a given habitat, a mechanism that results in clustering of traits in local species assemblages. Alternatively, limiting similarity occurs when species with similar traits competitively exclude each other, producing an assemblage with traits that are highly divergent (i.e., overdispersed compared to random expectation). Trait dispersion patterns can be used to determine the importance of niche-based processes in structuring assemblages relative to neutral (i.e., random) processes. This project had three aims that address these issues: (1) examine knowledge gaps regarding functional diversity of stream fish assemblages at a global scale; (2) determine relative contribution of limiting similarity and environmental filtering to neutral processes at three spatial scales; and (3) assess changes in functional diversity and community assembly processes across environment and species richness gradients.

Convergence of trait–habitat relationships across evolutionary and biogeographically distinct assemblages would suggest key, repeated mechanisms play a role in structuring assemblages along environmental gradients. However, few studies at the assemblage level have involved analyzing quantitative data collected using standardized methods at a global scale to study such convergence. In this study, we tested the hypothesis that trait–habitat relationships converge across zoogeographic regions due to universal environmental filters acting on functional traits. Fish assemblages of 40 small streams were sampled at three spatial scales (microhabitat, stream reach, region). The streams spanned five distinct zoogeographic regions: North America, South America, Central America, Asia, and Africa. The dataset included 197 species of teleost fish. Using thirty functional traits and various multivariate techniques, the convergence of trait–habitat relations were analyzed within and across zoogeographic regions for single traits and trait groups.

Convergence of trait–habitat relationships was widespread and often strong, yet not universal. Habitat features, such as substrate and water velocity, were shown to filter traits found in certain habitat types across all regions, suggesting that these features act as universal environmental filters. Fish functional diversity was positively correlated with the amount of submerged structures and variation of water velocity, a finding that has strong implications for biodiversity conservation. Although many instances of species convergence were documented, phylogenetic constraint (i.e., closely related species have similar functional traits) also played a strong role in shaping trait distributions in these fish assemblages.

General patterns as well as regionally unique habitat–trait relationships were discovered during this project. Findings provide a foundation for predictive models to advance biodiversity conservation in streams of these and other regions of the world. Because some trait-habitat relationships differed for certain zoogeographic regions, these relationships need to be tested for each region before assemblage–habitat relationships can be used for management.

Fieldwork created many opportunities for mentoring several undergraduate students, graduates students and local scientists as well as educating local citizens about biodiversity and ecological sustainability. During the field campaign to Cambodia, the doctoral candidate and his advisor taught workshops for local scientists and students on low-cost, low-tech methods for fisheries research and management. In Benin, the candidate mentored graduate students on fish and habitat survey methods. The candidate taught a geometric morphometrics workshop and field collection techniques to students and faculty at the Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Brazil. Several US and international students gained research experience while assisting with field and laboratory work. Researchers discussed biodiversity and ecological sustainability issues with people encountered during fieldwork at each location.
